author: Jason Beattie
title: The first signs of Brexit regret: Mirror Politics morning briefing
text:
The Google survey of more than 44,000 readers of Mirror websites found 13% of those who voted to Leave last June would now switch to Remain, while 9% of those who voted Remain would now vote out. 
These switches would, if repeated at a national level, reverse the result of the referendum. 
As with all public opinion exercises it should carry a health warning. It is a snapshot rather than a forecast. 
For a start, it is not a poll which are weighted by age, geography and class and use previous polls as benchmarks. 
But the sheer size of then Google survey and that fact it is of Mirror website readers makes it of interest. There are mixed results for Theresa May in the Mirror survey (Photo: Getty) 
The findings also show that a majority of people believe Theresa May was right to put regaining control of our borders as the priority for Brexit. 
The Prime Minister also comes out strongly when people are asked their opinions of party leaders. 
The survey also underlines that Jeremy Corbyn has a long way to go before he can convince people he is a credible Prime Minister in waiting . 
Corbyn’s fate could hinge on what happens in next week’s by-elections in Copeland and Stoke. 
My colleague Ben Glaze has now been to test the waters (and probably, like any self-respecting journalist, the beers) in both seats. 
It is noticeable that even some of Corbyn's strongest supporters in Parliament are now speculating about how long he should stay if there is no turn around in Labour’s fortunes. 
Ian Lavery, the party’s new campaign manager, said there were plenty of potential leaders waiting in the wings should Corbyn decide to stand down “of his own volition.” 
Parliament is on a half-term break this week which may be reflected in the morning newsletter. Jeremy Corbyn's fate could hinge on the results of next week's by-elections (Photo: Getty) 
Brexit Secretary David Davis is on a visit to Finland and Sweden. 
Justice Secretary Liz Truss is giving a speech on prisons today in which, given the opportunity to make a thoughtful contribution about overcrowding, rehabilitation and recidivism, has chosen to go for cheap headlines that channel the worst of Michael Howard’s ‘prison works’ rhetoric. 
These are words I never expected to type: please come back Michael Gove.
